title: How to Boil Ham

steps.headline: Thaw the ham well before cooking if purchased frozen.
steps.description: A frozen ham can be thawed in a fridge overnight or soaked in cold water for a few hours. If you bought a cured ham, soaking for a few hours is suggested to remove some of the saltiness. Take the ham out of the fridge two hours before cooking to ensure that it will boil evenly.

steps.headline: Remove the skin, if necessary.
steps.description: Make an incision toward the bottom of the shank (where the ham becomes more narrow) with a sharp knife and peel back the skin gently. Be sure to leave the layer of fat (the white part) intact. The skin can be saved and used as a soup base, or sliced and deep-fried for homemade pork rinds.

steps.headline: Place the ham in a large pot.
steps.description: Make sure the ham won't get stuck in the pot, but also ensure that the ham isn't allowed to move that much. This will help you control the cooking process.

steps.headline: Fill the pot up to ¾ full with cold water.
steps.description: Add desired seasonings, stock or wine but be careful not to overfill the pot.

steps.headline: Bring the water up to temperature.
steps.description: Once it begins to boil, reduce the heat so that the ham begins to simmer and place a lid on the pot. Estimated cooking time is 20 to 25 minutes per pound once the water reaches a boil. Scoop up and discard any foam that forms on top with a slotted spoon.

steps.headline: Check for doneness with a meat thermometer.
steps.description: Insert the thermometer into the deepest part of the meat and read the temperature. Suggested internal temperature for ham is 155 °F (68 °C). If you’re glazing your ham, stop boiling before the ham reaches 155 °F (68 °C). The glazing process requires a trip to the oven, which will continue to cook the ham.

steps.headline: Leave the ham to rest in the liquid for several hours.
steps.description: The ham will continue to absorb the flavors of the seasoned water and become cool enough to handle for the glazing and/or carving process.

steps.headline: Score the ham if you wish to glaze it.
steps.description: Trim the fat to about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick. Then make cuts into the remaining fat in a cross-hatch pattern. This will help the glaze seep deeper into the meat. If you’re not glazing your ham, skip ahead to Step 4. Try not to pierce the meat itself when scoring.

steps.headline: Make the glaze and spread it over the ham.
steps.description: Cover as much of the top side of the ham as you can.

steps.headline: Place the glazed ham in a pan and put it in a pre-heated, 400 °F (204 °C) oven.
steps.description: Bake for 15 minutes or until the glaze has turned a nice, golden brown.

steps.headline: Let the ham rest 20 minutes before carving.
steps.description: The ham will be extremely hot when it’s done, making it nearly impossible to cut properly.

steps.headline: Carve the ham along the bone if you bought a bone-in ham.
steps.description: Using a sharp knife or electric slicer, make a cut parallel to the bone, then make a cut at a 45 degree angle. Remove the wedge of meat you just made, then begin making thin slices perpendicular to the bone. Take the slices you made a handful at a time and move them to a serving platter. The bone, like the skin of a fresh ham, can also be saved and used as a delicious soup base.

steps.headline: Cut a boneless ham in half and make slices from each half.
steps.description: This will help regulate the size of each slice you carve. For best results, use a freshly sharpened knife or electric slicer.

steps.headline: Refrigerate leftovers when the feast is over.
steps.description: Place the ham in a sealed container and enjoy it again for up to a week afterwards. If you wish to freeze the ham, you can preserve it in a freezer-safe container for up to a month.
